value: Lübbecke from the Wiehen Hills. In the foreground is the Old Town and St. Andrew's Church; in the background, the industrial estate and North German Plain

is a picturesque, little town in the northeast of the state of
at the foot of the Wiehen Hills (
), the last ridge before you reach the North German Plain.

Lübbecke lies in the southwestern part of the district of Minden-Lübbecke and in the western part of the region of Minden Land. Most of the town itself lies on the lowlands of the North German Plain, but its southern quarters stretch up the northern hillside of the ridge known as the Wiehen Hills. Apart from the ridge and the main town, most of the borough is flat and rural in character. Its northern boundary is the Midland Canal (
), whilst its southern boundary is the crest of the Wiehen Hills. To the northeast of the town is

, the largest moor in Westphalia.

The highest hill in Lübbecke's territory is the
(320 m) on the Wiehen ridge. However the slightly lower
to the north is probably better known as it is crowned by a small stone observation tower, the
, that is the turning point of the annual 14 kilometre race of the same name that starts and ends in Lübbecke.
From the A 30 motorway, take junction 29, signed B 239, Lübbecke. The town lies on the B 239 about 15 kilometres north of the junction.

Lübbecke Station lies on the Ravensberg Railway (route no. 386), and has an hourly service (every 2 hours on Sundays) that works the Regionalbahn 71 route from Bielefeld via Herford and Bünde to Rahden.

value: directions=half way down the high street
content=Good location in the pedestrianised high street of Lübbecke. Delicious cakes and good coffee; great place to relax outside in sunny weather and watch the world go by.
